title: Boxplot: Outlier Effect on the Mean and Standard Deviation
question_text:

Looking at the modified boxplot, what will happen to the mean and standard deviation when the outlier of $23$ is removed?
Looking at the modified boxplot, what will happen to the mean and standard deviation when the outlier of $23$ is removed?

choices.text: The mean and and standard deviation will both decrease.
The mean will decrease, but the standard deviation will increase.
The mean and standard deviation will both increase.
The mean will increase, but the standard deviation will decrease.
The mean and standard deviation will remain the same.

solution:
The mean and standard deviation are non-resistant measures of center and spread respectively. This indicates the mean and standard deviation will change in response to data addition or removal. Therefore, Choice 'E' can be eliminated.

When we remove the low outlier of
23
the mean will increase since the mean gets lower when the value of
23
is included. As a result, Choices 'A' and 'B' can be eliminated.

Standard deviation is how far the individual values vary from the mean.

By removing the low outlier of
23
the values will be more concentrated (thus closer) around the mean than before. This will create a smaller spread about the mean. Therefore, the standard deviation will decrease. Choice 'C' can be eliminated.

As a result, Choice 'D' is our answer because mean will increase (since the set is losing a lower contributing value) and standard deviation will decrease (smaller spread around mean).
